description: This presentation/discussion-oriented course is to train PhD students to conduct and report a neurolinguistic experiment with a chosen cognitive neuroscience technique, such as event-related brain potential (ERP) or functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). Students are expected to find their interested topic at the beginning of the semester, compile a list of literature, design their own experiment according to their chosen technique, and run a pilot test with a few participants. They then have to analyze the data, present the results to the class and write up a short term paper in a journal format.
goals: Students can independently find a research idea and effectively do literature review.

Students can have hands-on experience with software necessary for experiment design and data processing, such as E-prime (commercial behavioral experiment software), ERPLAB (a free Matlab package for analyzing ERP data), SPM (a free Matlab package for analyzing fMRI data), and a statistical package of their choice (e.g. SPSS).
Students can confidently run an experiment with the necessary equipment(s) and comfortably interact with participants.
Students can write a paper in a journal format in the cognitive neuroscience domain.
syllabus:
This presentation/discussion-oriented course is to train PhD students to conduct and report a neurolinguistic experiment with a chosen cognitive neuroscience technique, such as event-related brain potential (ERP) or functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). Students are expected to find their interested topic at the beginning of the semester, compile a list of literature, design their own experiment according to their chosen technique, and run a pilot test with a few participants. They then have to analyze the data, present the results to the class and write up a short term paper in a journal format.

Week 1 Introduction

Week 2 Research topic search: Research question(s)

Week 3 Research topic search: List(s) ofreferences

Week 4 Hypothesis: Hypothesis for the currentstudy based on previous findings

Week 5 Experiment design: Experimental factors andsample materials I

Week 6 Experiment design: Experimental factors andsample materials II

Week 7 Experiment design: E-prime stimulus presentation

Week 8 Experiment design: E-prime script(s)testing with the ERP/fMRI machine

Week 9 Experiment design: Experiment finalization(with necessary manipulation)

Week 10 Data collection (at the NeurolinguisticsLab at NTNU or the fMRI center at NTU

or NCCU)

Week 11 Data collection (at the NeurolinguisticsLab at NTNU or the fMRI center at NTU

or NCCU)

Week 12 Data analysis: Individual subject analysis(ERPLAB/SPM)

Week 13 Data analysis: Individual subject analysis(ERPLAB/SPM)

Week 14 Data analysis: Group analysis (ERPLAB/SPM)

Week 15 Data analysis: Group analysis (ERPLAB/SPM)

Week 16 Results: Graphs and statistical resultssupporting or rejecting the hypothesis

Week 17 Results: Data interpretation in thecontext of previous research

Week 18 Final presentation(in a conference presentation format)

methodologies.note: In the first 15-20 minutes of each class, the instructor will give a short lecture to direct students to the details that they need to pay attention to in their own and their peers’ presentations.
Students will give presentations and the instructor and other students will provide suggestions/comments through discussion.
Students are expected to run an ERP or fMRI experiment with a few participants and analyze data with software.

grading.note: Students should be able to address the instructor’s comments/suggestions and should be able to provide comments/suggestions for other students’ work.

Students will give 5 presentations throughout the semester:
#1: Research topic 
#2: Experiment design (with E-prime)
#3: Data analysis (with ERPLAB or SPM)
#4: Results (with graphs and statistical results)
#5: Final presentation (in a conference presentation format)
A short term paper in a journal format. Students have to choose a journal in the cognitive neuroscience domain and follow their submission guidelines to write up the paper.
